lecture 4: Formal definition of a function, simple examples of functions (linear, quadratic), how to draw them and how to figure out their domain and range.

What is a function?

1. Motivational Real-World Example

Vending Machine Analogy:
A vending machine takes in a selection code (e.g., A1, B2) and gives you a unique snack. If you press A1, you always get the same item. It doesn't give two snacks, and it doesn't give you different items each time.
That’s the essence of a function: Each input leads to exactly one output.

2. Formal Definition

A function is a rule that assigns each element from a set called the domain to exactly one element in another set called the range.

Notation:
f:A→Bf:A\to Bf:A→B, where f(x)∈Bf(x) \in Bf(x)∈B for each x∈Ax \in Ax∈A.
(AAA is the domain and BBB is the range.)

3. Domain and Range

  • Domain: All the inputs xxx for which the function is defined.
  • Range: All possible outputs f(x)f(x)f(x) the function can produce.

Two functions can have the same domain and range but be completely different rules.
(e.g., f(x)=xf(x)=xf(x)=x vs. g(x)=−xg(x)=−xg(x)=−x).

Co-domain vs. Range

  • Co-domain: The set of all possible outputs that could be produced by the function.
  • Range: The set of all actual outputs that are produced by the function.

So, the range is a subset of the co-domain.

Example:
f(x)=x2f(x)=x^2f(x)=x2

  • Co-domain: all real numbers
  • Range: all non-negative real numbers

4. Why Do We Care?

  • Functions are how we model relationships between quantities: position vs. time, cost vs. production, temperature vs. altitude.

  • In calculus, functions are the primary objects of study for understanding change and motion.

5. Examples

  • A temperature converter: F=95C+32F = \frac{9}{5}C + 32F=59​C+32
  • A vending machine: f(button,money)=snackf(\text{button}, \text{money}) = \text{snack}f(button,money)=snack
  • A calculator: pressing "=" gives you the result of the expression you entered.
    • This is a function because each input (expression) gives exactly one output (result).

Examples of mappings that are not functions:

  • Person to their phone number: a person can have multiple phone numbers.
  • Restaurant menu special: a special can change every day.
  • Birthday to person: same birthday maps to multiple people.
  • Language translation: same word can have multiple meanings.

Questions:

  • Is ChatGPT a function?
  • Is Google search a function?

Linear Functions

1. Example

If you earn 10 Riyals for every hour worked: y=10xy=10xy=10x is a linear function.

2. General Form

f(x)=mx+bf(x)=mx+b f(x)=mx+b

  • m = slope (rate of change)
  • b = y-intercept (starting value)

3. Graph

  • Always a straight line.
  • Slope = rise/run.
  • Domain = all real numbers (R\mathbb{R}R)
  • Range = all real numbers (R\mathbb{R}R)

Example:
Graph of f(x)=2x+1f(x)=2x+1f(x)=2x+1:

Quadratic Functions

1. Why Use Quadratics?

Used to model things like:

  • Projectile motion
  • Revenue as a function of sales
  • Area as a function of side length

2. General Form

f(x)=ax2+bx+cf(x)=ax^2+bx+c f(x)=ax2+bx+c

  • Parabolic shape (opens up if a>0a>0a>0, down if a<0a<0a<0)
  • Vertex is turning point

3. Domain and Range

  • Domain: R\mathbb{R}R
  • Range:
    • If a>0a>0a>0, [min,∞)[\text{min},\infty)[min,∞)
    • If a<0a<0a<0, (−∞,max](−\infty,\text{max}](−∞,max]

Example:
Graph of f(x)=x2−2x+1f(x)=x^2−2x+1f(x)=x2−2x+1

  • Domain: all real numbers
  • Range: depends on the minimum point. In this case, the minimum point is at y=0y=0y=0.

4. Vertex

The vertex of a quadratic function is the point where the function changes direction.

The x-coordinate of the vertex of a quadratic function f(x)=ax2+bx+cf(x)=ax^2+bx+cf(x)=ax2+bx+c is given by the formula:

x=−b2ax=-\frac{b}{2a} x=−2ab​

The y-coordinate of the vertex is then found by plugging the x-coordinate back into the function.

Example:
f(x)=x2−2x+1f(x)=x^2-2x+1f(x)=x2−2x+1

  • The x-coordinate of the vertex is x=−−22(1)=1x=-\frac{-2}{2(1)}=1x=−2(1)−2​=1.
  • The y-coordinate of the vertex is f(1)=12−2(1)+1=0f(1)=1^2-2(1)+1=0f(1)=12−2(1)+1=0.
  • The vertex is at (1,0)(1,0)(1,0).

Function evaluation

If given a formula, function evaluated at a point is the value of the function at that point.

Examples:

  • f(x)=x2+2x+1f(x)=x^2+2x+1f(x)=x2+2x+1
    • f(−1)=(−1)2+2(−1)+1=0f(-1)=(-1)^2+2(-1)+1=0f(−1)=(−1)2+2(−1)+1=0
  • g(x)=2x+3g(x)=2^{x+3}g(x)=2x+3
    • g(2)=22+3=25=32g(2)=2^{2+3}=2^5=32g(2)=22+3=25=32

By the same logic, we can evaluate functions at points represented by expressions.

Examples:

  • f(x)=x2+2x+1f(x)=x^2+2x+1f(x)=x2+2x+1
    • f(−x)=(−x)2+2(−x)+1=x2−2x+1f(-x)=(-x)^2+2(-x)+1=x^2-2x+1f(−x)=(−x)2+2(−x)+1=x2−2x+1
    • f(2y)=(2y)2+2(2y)+1=4y2+4y+1f(2y)=(2y)^2+2(2y)+1=4y^2+4y+1f(2y)=(2y)2+2(2y)+1=4y2+4y+1
    • f(x+1)=(x+1)2+2(x+1)+1=x2+2x+1+2x+2+1=x2+4x+4f(x+1)=(x+1)^2+2(x+1)+1=x^2+2x+1+2x+2+1=x^2+4x+4f(x+1)=(x+1)2+2(x+1)+1=x2+2x+1+2x+2+1=x2+4x+4

Regular Exercises

1. Water Tank Domain and Range

A water tank is being drained. The function h(t)h(t)h(t) gives the amount of water (in liters) left in the tank after ttt minutes.
The tank starts full at 100 liters, and drains at 5 liters per minute, until empty.

  • a) Write a possible rule for h(t)h(t)h(t).
  • b) What is the domain of h(t)h(t)h(t)?
  • c) What is the range of h(t)h(t)h(t)?
  • d) Could this function continue forever?

2. Photo Frame

You have a square photo print with side length xxx centimeters. You want to add a frame of constant width 222 centimeters all around it.

  • Suppose you have exactly 100 cm2100 \text{ cm}^2100 cm2 of frame material available.
    • Write and solve an equation to find the side length of the photo that would exactly use up the available frame material.

Hint: Write the area of the frame as a function of xxx, and then solve for xxx.

3. Quadratic Function Construction

Construct a quadratic function f(x)f(x)f(x) that satisfies the following:

  • The vertex is at (2,−3)(2,−3)(2,−3)
  • f(0)=5f(0)=5f(0)=5

4. Reverse Engineering a Function

You are given that:

  • f(0)=2f(0)=2f(0)=2

  • f(1)=5f(1)=5f(1)=5

  • f(2)=8f(2)=8f(2)=8

  • f(3)=11f(3)=11f(3)=11

    • a) Can you guess a formula for f(x)f(x)f(x)?
    • b) Is your function linear or nonlinear? How can you tell?
    • c) Could more than one rule produce these values? Why or why not?

Extra Advanced Exercises

1. Fencing a Rectangular Area

You are given 40 meters of fencing and want to enclose a rectangular area against a wall (so you only need to fence three sides). Let xxx be the width of the fenced rectangle.

  • a) Write a function A(x)A(x)A(x) for the area in terms of xxx.
  • b) What is the domain of A(x)A(x)A(x)?
  • c) Find the value of xxx that gives the maximum area, and explain how you know it's a maximum.

2. Composing Functions

You’re told that:

h(x)=2x+3h(x)=\sqrt{2x+3} h(x)=2x+3​

And someone tells you it came from composing two functions fff and ggg, so that
h(x)=f(g(x))h(x)=f(g(x))h(x)=f(g(x))

  • a) Find at least one possible pair (f,g)(f,g)(f,g) such that this is true.
  • b) Can you find a different pair of functions that also work?
  • c) What is the domain of h(x)h(x)h(x)? How does that relate to the domains of fff and ggg?
